File.Title: The Connections of the Peripeduncular Area Studied by Retrograde and Anterograde Transport in the Rat

Abstract.S: Lying just ventral to the medial geniculate nucleus and dorsal to the cerebral peduncle, the peripeduncular area (PPA) seems to be implicated in the expression of several sexual reflexes in rodents.

The aim of the present investigation was to establish the organization of the afferent and efferent projections of the rat's PPA in an attempt to provide a neural substrate corresponding to the behavioral observations.

Based on both retrograde and anterograde transport methods, our results suggest that the PPA: 1) receives its main afferent projections from the insulotemporal cortex, basal ganglia, ventromedial and posterior hypothalamic nuclei, zona incerta, inferior colliculus, intermediate and deep layers of the superior colliculus, central gray, cuneiform nucleus, laterodorsal tegmental nucleus, and dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus and, 2) projects essentially to the basal ganglia, ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus, central gray, cuneiform and pedunculopontine nuclei, deep layers of the superior collic-ulus, inferior colliculus, and dorsal and ventral nuclei of the lateral lemniscus.

These findings, indicating that the PPA is connected with the auditory, motor, and limbic systems and with nonspecific diencephalic and mesencephalic centers, are in agreement with the notion that in rodents this area might play a role in the female sexual receptivity (as expressed by lordosis display or ultrasound production) or male mounting behavior.

Introduction.S: In rodents the sexually receptive female displays several characteristic types of behavior such as lordosis and ultrasound production (see review in Kirn and Floody, '85; Yamanouchi et al., '85), which are under the control of both internal (oestrogenic induction) and external (contacts by the male's forearms on the female flanks) stimuli (Kow and Pfaff, '76).

Investigations of the neural substrates of sexual receptivity have focused on diencephalic, hormone-dependent centers and on mesodiencephalic structures thought to be responsible for the expression of these behavioral characteristics (Sakuma and Pfaff, '79a, b).

The peripeduncular nucleus is one of the mesodiencephalic centers that seems to be implicated in the expression of the lordosis reflex (Carrer, '78; Edwards and Pfeifle, '81; Pfeifle and Edwards, '83; L6pez and Carrer, '85b).
This nucleus belongs to the lateral tegmentum.
Caudally, it is located beneath the medial geniculate nucleus and 10strally, beneath the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus.
It is limited ventrally by the dorsal cap of the cerebral peduncle.
No systematic study of the overall pattern of connections of the peripeduncular nucleus has yet been reported.

On the one hand, however, this nucleus has been described as projecting to the amygdaloid complex (see Ottersen, '81) and basal nucleus of Meynert (Jones et al., '76) and as being reciprocally connected with the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus (see Krieger et al., '79; Kita and Oomura, '82b).

On the other hand, the peripeduncular nucleus is sometimes regarded in the cat and the monkey as being the analogue of the interstitial nucleus of the brachium of the inferior colliculus and, as such, is considered to belong to the auditory system.
This interpretation is supported by the fact that fibers arising from the inferior colliculus (Moore and Goldberg, '63, '66; Powell and Hatton, '69) and from the Address reprint requests to M.
Roger, Laboratoire de Neurophysiologie, CNRS: UA 290, Facult6 des Sciences, 86022 Poitiers, France.
in auditory cortex (Diamond et al., '69) appear to terminate the peripeduncular nucleus.
The aim of the present investigation is to establish the organization of the afferent and efferent projections of the peripeduncular nucleus in the rat.

Since the medial borders of this region are difficult to establish with precision in this species, the expression peripeduncular area (PPA) is preferred to peripeduncular nucleus in the present study.

Afferent connections were identified by using the retrograde transport of either horseradish peroxidase (HRP) or wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to HRP (WGA-HRP), whereas the efferent system of connections was studied by using the anterograde transport of WGA-HRP.
This tracer is currently used as an anterograde label to trace axonal pathways (Trojanowski et al., '81; Mesulam, '82; Mantyh and Peschanski, '83; Peschanski and Ralston, '85).
This technique offers the advantage of being easy to use and sensitive, especially when tetramethylbenzidine is employed as the chromogen.
In addition, the precise organization of several projections was further examined following tracer application into some of the centers identified as being connected with the PPA.

Methods.S: This study is based on the results obtained from 25 hooded and albino rats (15 males and 10 females) weighing 250320 g.
Horseradish peroxidase (Sigmad, type VI) or WGA-HRP (Sigma) was introduced under chloral hydrate anesthesia into the peripeduncular area of 14 animals.
In order to obtain a limited zone of enzyme application, the method described by Mori et al. ('81) was chosen.

In short, the tips of glass micropipettes (outside diameter 50 pm) were filled with crystalline HRP (cases R2, R13, R14, R15, R17, R23, R30, and R31) or WGA-HRP (cases R36, R38, R47, R52, R71, and R72).
The size of the application areas obtained depended on the quantity of enzyme introduced in the tip of the pipettes.
After cranial trephining and dural reflection, the micropipettes were stereotaxically lowered into the PPA according to the coordinates derived from the atlas of Pellegrino et al. ('79).

A vertical lowering was undertaken in 7 animals; in the remaining 7 cases the tracer was deposited following an oblique approach at 50" to the horizontal plane to avoid any leakage of the tracer in the medial geniculate nucleus during the lowering of the micropipette.
Eleven rats were used as controls.

The tracer (WGA-HRP) was deposited in the following centers: insulotemporal cortex (cases R61, R62, and R75), inferior colliculus (cases R67, R68, and R69), basal ganglia (cases R56, R60), and medial geniculate nucleus (cases R4, R51, and R73).
The pipettes were affixed to the skull with dental acrylic and left in place during a survival period of 48 hours.

The animals were then perf'used transcardially under deep anesthesia with a solution of 750 ml of a 1% paraformaldehyde-1.25% glutaraldehyde fixative made up in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, followed by 750 ml of cold (4°C) 0.1 M phosphate buffer containing 10% saccharose.
The brains were then removed and 50 pm-thick frozen sections were collected and treated with tetramethylbenzidine and hydrogen peroxide according to the procedure described by Mesulam ('78).
Alternate sections were mounted on gelatincoated slides and then either directly coverslipped or counterstained with alum carmine.

The exact position of the labeled neurons (retrograde tracing experiments) or labeled axons (anterograde tracing experiments) was plotted on magnified drawings of the sections with the aid of a camera lucida.

Results.S: The sizes of the diffusion zones of the tracers are illustrated in Figures 1 and 2.
Cases in which the tracer was observed to spread into the medial geniculate or in which the cerebral peduncle was sectioned while lowering the micropipette were discarded.

TTE.S: Sources of afferent input to the PPA
The results of the retrograde tracing experiments were obtained from 14 animals (HRP: 8 cases; WGA-HRP: 6 cases).
Since in both groups (HRP and WGA-HRP) the density and localization of the retrograde cell labeling did not differ significantly, the results were pooled.
The structures consistently found to contain retrogradely labeled perikarya are listed in Table l.
Case R36 was selected to illustrate the overall input to the PPA (Fig. 3).
Unless otherwise specified, the reported afferents are ipsilateral in origin.
Ipsilateral or contralateral will mean ipsilateral or contralateral to the tracer implant.
Cerebral cortex.
A substantial cell labeling was observed in the insulotemporal region, essentially in Krieg's ('46) areas 13, 20, and, to a much lesser extent, in the temporal area 41 (Fig. 3c-h).
Most of those labeled cells were located in layer V.
Their morphology appeared to be characteristic of pyramidal cells (Fig. 4a), with a basal diameter generally comprised between 15 and 25 pm.
The other cortical areas were entirely devoid of labeled perikarya.
Basal ganglia.

Labeled neurons consistently occurred in the following nuclei: the caudoventral division of the caudate-putamen (CPU), caudal sector of the globus pallidus (GP), basal nucleus of Meynert, and the narrow band bordered dorsally by the internal capsule and ventrally by the optic tract (Fig. 3b).
The labeled cells showed distinct morphological characteristics according to their localization.

In the CPU the labeled cells were round and rather small (diameter 15-35 pm), whereas in the GP they were multipolar and larger (diameter 20-40 pm) (Fig. 5d) and in the basal nucleus they were mostly fusiform (major axis length 60 pm).
In contrast, only sparse retrograde labeling was present in the amygdaloid complex.
The central nucleus of the amygdala was observed to contain a few labeled cells in only 7 out of the 14 cases.
Diencephalon
Hypothalamus.
Following deposits of the tracer in the PPA, bilateral cell labeling (Fig. 3a, b) occurred in the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus (VMH).

In the ipsilateral side the retrograde cell labeling was dense, systematic, and regularly distributed in the dorsomedial and ventrolateral subdivisions of the nucleus (Fig. 5b), whereas in the contralateral side the VMH contained a few positive cells only.
The posterior nucleus (Fig. 3c) and, to a lesser extent, the medial preoptic area and the lateral hypothalamic area (Fig. 3b) were also labeled.
Subthalamus and thalamus.
Retrograde cell labeling was evident in three sectors (Fig. 3b-d) of the zona incerta: pars anteropolaris, ventralis, and posteropolaris (following the nomenclature of Watanabe and Kawana, '82).

The thalamus appeared almost devoid of retrograde cell labeling except for a slight and inconsistent labeling in the suprageniculate nucleus and along a narrow band located in the dorsomedial sector of the lateral posterior nucleus (Fig. 3e).
Midbrain and isthmus regions
The inferior colliculus (CIF) was found to supply a very large input to the PPA (Fig. 3g-i).
Labeled cells were distributed along the whole rostrocaudal extent of the CIF.

In most cases, the densest labeling was found in the periphery of the CIF and especially in the region of the intercollicular commissural zone, whereas the central nucleus was almost free of retrograde labeling (Fig. 6).
Sparse labeling was also apparent in the contralateral CIF.
The intermediate and deep layers of the superior colliculus were found to provide Pons
A large number of labeled neurons were consistently found in the entire extent of the ipsilateral cuneiform nucleus.
The contralateral nucleus was also labeled, but to a lesser degree (Fig. 3h).
Bilateral retrograde labeling was evident in three other pontine areas: the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus, the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, and, occasionally, the dorsal raphe (Fig. 3h).
Fig. 7b), and ventral.
The densest labeling was found in the dorsal sector of the central gray (dCG).
However, the central sector (cCG) and, to a much lesser extent, the contralateral dorsal and central sectors were also significantly labeled (Fig. 3 f-h).
Forebrain
No significant anterograde labeling could be detected in the cortex following deposit of the tracer in the PPA.
In contrast, anterograde labeling systematically occurred within the basal ganglia (Fig. 7a).
The globus pallidus and basal nucleus of Meynert displayed a relatively high degree of axonal labeling.
The caudal part of the caudate-putamen complex was also heavily labeled.
Occasionally, diffuse axonal labeling was noted in the caudal division of the lateral nucleus of the amygdala.
Diencephalon
The ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus was most heavily labeled (Fig. 7a).
The labeled area covered the entire extent of the nucleus (Fig. 4b).
In most cases, a weaker pattern of anterograde labeling was noted in the contralatera1 VMH.
In addition, slight anterograde labeling was observed in the lateral hypothalamic area.
Dense to moderate anterograde labeling was also observed in the zona incerta.

Whereas many labeled axons were found coursing through the caudal ZI, presumed axon terminals were noted in the ventral half of pars ventralis (Watanabe and Kawana, '82) and in pars anteropolaris (Fig. 7a).
Brainstem and pons
Dense anterograde labeling occurred in three mesencephalic areas.
The cuneiform nucleus was densely labeled in its whole rostrocaudal extent (Fig. 7%).
In most cases diffuse anterograde labeling was also present in the contralateral nucleus.
The central gray was heavily labeled in its dorsal sector (dCG) (Figs. 4c, 7b); less densely in its central sector (cCG) (Fig. 7b).
The deep layers of the superior colliculus (stratum griseum profundum and stratum album profundum) displayed a heavy anterograde labeling, mainly in their medial half.

Finally, moderate to light labeling was observed in the following areas: caudal inferior colliculus (ventral and medial divisions), dorsal and ventral nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, and pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus (Fig. 7b).

Results.S: A series of control experiments was devised to verify that the findings reported above concerning the connections with the auditory system were not the consequence of a tracer diffusion in the adjacent medial geniculate nucleus (GM).
For this purpose, WGA-HRP was deposited in the following centers.

TTE.S: Deposits in the GM.
The pattern of cortical labeling was fundamentally different from the pattern obtained following tracer deposits in the PPA (Fig. 8).
Application of WGAHRP into the medial geniculate induced a pattern of labeling almost restricted to the auditory area 41.
Anterograde labeling was present mainly in layer IV and retrograde labeling occurred in layer V and, to a lesser extent, in layer VI.
(Fig. 9a-c).
Only sparse retrograde cell labeling could be noted in the insulotemporal cortex (areas 13 and 20 of Krieg, '46).
Within the inferior colliculus the retrograde labeling was also markedly different.

In contrast to the pattern of labeling induced by deposits in the PPA, positive neurons systematically occurred in the central nucleus, whereas the periphery of the CIF appeared almost devoid of retrograde labeling.

Finally, following introduction of the tracer into the GM, densely labeled neurons systematically occurred in the reticular thalamic nucleus, whereas tracer deposits restricted to the PPA failed to label thalamic reticular neurons.
Other connections of the GM that fall outside the scope of this study will not be detailed.
Tracer applications in the insulotemporal cortex (Fig. 1Oc) induced moderate to dense anterograde labeling in the PPA, mainly within its laterodorsal division.
Sparse retrograde labeling was also apparent in the more medial division of the PPA (Fig.
'Ob) suggesting not detected in the anterograde study of the PPA efferents, a weakPPA projection to the temporal cortex might exist.
Following WGA-HRP introduction into the CIF(Fig. llb), two areas were labeled within the PPA.
A dense zone of anterograde labeling occurred in a sector just ventral to the GM, whereas retrograde labeling was apparent more ventrally, next to the dorsal cap of the cerebral peduncle (Fig. lla).

Results.S: WGA-HRP is not known to be taken up and transported by fibers of passage.
However, passing axons might have been injured during the lowering of the electrode, thus leading to some tracer incorporation.

This is the reason why a second category of experiments was devised to verify that the above reported connections with the basal ganglia were not the consequence of a tracer uptake by injured axons coursing through or in the vicinity of the cerebral peduncle.

TTE.S: Following tracer applications in the caudoventral sector of the CPU, including the GP, both anterograde and retrograde labeling were observed within the PPA (Fig. 12).

Retrograde labeling occurred in the dorsal division of the PPA just ventral to the GM and, more ventrally, in an area situated above the lateral division of the substantia nigra, whereas a dense zone of anterograde labeling was observed in the ventral PPA.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
The present findings indicate that the rat's peripeduncular area is connected with a relatively large variety of neural centers, most of which are reported here for the first time.
Our findings indicate that the PPA is connected with the auditory, motor, and limbic systems, and with nonspecific diencephalic and mesencephalic centers.
Anatomical considerations

In this study, the PPA is shown to receive fibers from the insulotemporal cortex (secondary auditory area of Zilles et al., '801, inferior colliculus and dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus (DLL), and, in turn, to project to the CIF, DLL, and ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus (VLL).

Previous studies using degeneration techniques in the cat and the monkey have established that the czF projects to the region immediately ventral to the GM (Moore and Goldberg, '63, '66; Powell and Hatton, '69).
In an autoradiom-aDhic studv.
Kudo ('81) sueeested that the DLL also projects to this region.

Even thGLgh comparisons of cortical areas in rodents and carnivores are not easy to establish, it is interesting to note that large lesions of the auditory cortex-including the insulotemporal region-induce in the cat a pattern of degeneration in the peripeduncular region (Diamond et al., '69), a finding that corresponds with our results.
d
In an autoradiographic study, Jones et al. ('76) reported that in the monkey the peripeduncular nucleus projects heavily to the basal nucleus of Meynert and to the tail of the caudate nucleus.

Then again, even if comparisons of the morphological characteristics of the basal ganglia are difficult to establish between the rat and the monkey, our findings seem to be in agreement with the Jones et al. ('76) study.
It appears, however, that in the rat the connection between the basal ganglia and the PPA is reciprocally organized and that the globus pallidus also contributes to this projection.
The connections of the PPA with the limbic system have been described in a number of studies.

In the rat the PPA is known to be reciprocally connected with the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus (Conrad and Haff, '76; Saper et al., '76; De Olmos and Carrer, '78; Krieger et al., '79; Luiten and Room, '80; Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Kita and Oomura, '82a) and to give a projection to the lateral hypothalamic area (Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Kita and Oomura, '82b) and to the medial preoptic area (Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Kita and Oomura, '82a).

Besides, the PPA projects to the amygdaloid complex (the lateral nucleus, essentially) in the rat (Ottersen and Ben-Ari, '78, '79; Veening, '78; Nitecka, '79; Nitecka et al., '79; Ottersen, '81; Turner and Herkenham, '811, cat (Ottersen and Ben-Ari, '79; Russchen, '82; Maiskii et al., '84), and monkey (Jones et al., '76; Mehler et al., '78; Aggleton et al., '80; Mehler, '80).
Our findings are in agreement with those observations but suggest that the PPA also receives a relatively large projection from the posterior hypothalamic nucleus.
The present study further demonstrates that a system of connections links the PPA to nonspecific centers of the subthalamus and mesencephalon.

The present description of a projection from the PPA to the zona incerta is in agreement with a previous retrograde tracing study showing a relatively dense cell labeling in the PPA following WGA-HRP introduction into the ZI (Roger and Cadusseau, '85).
Efferent connections from the PPA to the cuneiform nucleus (Zemlan and Behbehani, '84) and to the central gray (Beitz, '82) have been reported in the rat.
In addition, our results suggest that these connections are reciprocally organized and that only a restricted sector (the dorsal sector) of the central gray is connected to the PPA.
Although not mentioned in the cat (Edwards and De Olmos, '761, the efferent connections from the CG and cuneiform nucleus to the PPA have been recently described in the rat by Eberhart et al. ('85).
Functional considerations
It has been established from lesion or stimulation experiments that the female sexual receptivity depends on the integrity of three neural systems.
First, an inhibitory sysd

tem lies in the following centers of the forebrain: septa1 nuclei (Zasorin et al., '75; Gorzalka and Gray, '81; Vomachka et al., '82; King and Nance, '85; Kirn and Floody, '85), lateral amygdala (Masco and Carrer, '80, '84), and medial preoptic area (Powers and Valenstein, '72).

Second, the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus has been described as a tonic activating, hormone-dependent center (Carrer et al., '73; Mathews and Edwards, '77; PfafT and Sakuma, '79; Manogue et al., '80; Lopez and Carrer, '82; Kow et al., '85; Lopez and Carrer, '85a).
Third, several mesencephalic centers appear to be directly concerned with the expression of the sexual female receptive or male mounting types of behavior.

As a matter of fact, bilateral lesions (Herndon, '76; Carrer, '78; Edwards and Pfeifle, '81; Hansen and Gummesson, '82; Pfeifle and Edwards, '83) or pentobarbital blockade (Lopez and Carrer, '85b) of the peripeduncular area induce a partial or total inhibition of the lordosis reflex in the female and suppress the mounting behavior in the male (Hansen and Gummesson, '82).
Other mesencephalic centers also contribute to the expression of receptivity in rodents.

Evidence supporting involvement of the central gray comes from lesion (Sakuma and Pfaff, '79b; Floody and ODonohue, '80) and from electrical or chemical stimulation experiments (Sakuma and Pfaff, '79a; Sirinathsinghji, '85).
Besides, synergic mechanisms appear to be represented within the CG.
Whereas the dorsal half exerts an excitatory role, the ventral half has an inhibitory influence on the lordosis reflex (Sakuma and Pfaff, '79b; Arndash and Gorski, '83; Yamanouchi and Arai, '85).

Interestingly, in the dorsal sector of the CG, the sites from which facilitation can be obtained overlap with those that receive a projection from the VMH (Krieger et al., '79; Sakuma and Pfaff, '79a; Beitz, '82).
In the present study, this same sector of the CG is reported to be heavily and reciprocally connected with the PPA.
Thus, there seems to exist a privileged triangular relationship between the VMH, PPA, and CG, the precise organization and role of which deserve further investigation.
Our findings, which suggest the existence of a large system of fibers connecting the PPA to auditory centers, might be in relation to the observations of Floody and O'Donohue ('80).
These authors established that in the sexually receptive female hamster, a lesion of the dorsolateral sector of the CG induces a decrease in ultrasound production.
Through the PPA, an auditory feedback might thus gain access to the neural circuitry sustaining the reflex of ultrasound vocalization in rodents.

In conclusion, our anatomical findings suggesting that the PPA is connected with limbic, motor, auditory, and nonspecific diencephalic and mesencephalic centers support the notion that this area might play a role in the female sexual receptivity as well as in the male mounting behavior.
Little is known about the neural mechanisms by which limbic processes gain access to the motor system.
On the basis of its large connections with the VMH on the one hand, and with the basal ganglia on the other hand, the PPA might play a key role in those types of sexual reflexes.
